Speaker: screenplay by
Dialogue: Rick Berman, Ronald D. Moore, Brannon Braga

Speaker: final draft
Dialogue: March 16, 1994

Speaker: chekov
Dialogue: There he is -- there, to the South!

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: What are ye, blind? That's a bird.

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: Repelling the Crystalline Trench... rafting down lava flows... orbital skydiving. it's like the man is running a bloody decathlon across the galaxy.

Speaker: chekov
Dialogue: That should be him now. I think he's just crossed the sound barrier.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Right on target! I jump out over the Arabian Peninsula... and I end up here, right on the dime.

Speaker: chekov
Dialogue: Actually, Captain, your precise target area was thirty-five meters...  That way.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Thanks for pointing that out.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Oh...

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: I've warned ye about that back of yours. You should have a doctor take a look at it.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Tomorrow I want to make a tri- elliptical jump. That's where you jump out over Northern China, and make three complete orbits before you start re-entry...

Speaker: chekov
Dialogue: Captain. Perhaps you have forgotten that tomorrow is the christening ceremony.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: I'm not going.  Scotty, help me with this chute.

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: What do you mean, you're not going? We promised.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: When I retired, I swore I'd never set foot on a starship again, and I meant it.

Speaker: chekov
Dialogue: Captain...

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: I don't want to hear anymore about it. I'm not going, and that's final.

Speaker: journalists
Dialogue: Captain Kirk, how does it feel to be back on the Enterprise Bridge... Captain, can I have a Minute... Captain Scott, do you have any comment on... Commander Chekov... etc.

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: Excuse me, excuse me...there will be plenty of time for questions later...

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: I'm Captain John Harriman. I'd like to welcome you all aboard.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: It's our pleasure.

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: I just want you to know how excited we all are to have a group of living legends with us on our maiden voyage.  I remember reading about your missions when I was in grade school.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Well... may we have a look around?

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: Please... please.

Speaker: chekov
Dialogue: Demora!

Speaker: journalist
Dialogue: So, Captain... this is the first Starship Enterprise in thirty years without James T. Kirk in command. How do you feel about that?

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Just fine. I'm glad to be here to send her on her way...

Speaker: journalist
Dialogue: What have you been doing since you retired?

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: I've been... keeping busy.

Speaker: chekov
Dialogue: Excuse me, Captain. I'd like you to meet the Helmsman of the Enterprise-B. Ensign Demora Sulu -- Captain James Kirk.

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: It's a pleasure to meet you, sir. My father's told me some... interesting stories about you.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Your father... Hikaru Sulu is your father?

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: chekov
Dialogue: You met her once before, but she was...

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: But that wasn't so long ago... it couldn't have been more than...

Speaker: chekov
Dialogue: Twelve years, sir.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Yes... well... congratulations, Ensign. It wouldn't be the Enterprise without a Sulu at the helm.

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: Thank you, sir.  Let me show you the new inertial guidance system.

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: Damn fine ship if you ask me...

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: You know, Scotty... it amazes me.

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: And what would that be, sir?

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Sulu. When did he find the time for a family?

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: It's like you always said -- if something's important enough, you make the time.

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: So... that's why you've been running around the galaxy like an eighteen-year-old. Finding retirement a little lonely, are we?

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: With that kind of tact, I'm glad you're an engineer and not a psychiatrist.

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: Excuse me, gentlemen... if you'll take your seats.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Oh... of course.

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: Captain Kirk, I'd be honored if you would give the order to get underway.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: No... no. Thank you.

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: Please, I insist.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Take us out.

Speaker: chekov
Dialogue: Very good, sir.

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: Brought a tear to my eye.

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: Well... we've just cleared the asteroid belt. Our course will take us out beyond Pluto and then back to spacedock. Just a quick run around the block.  If we have time, we'll conduct a few tests of the warp --

Speaker: com officer
Dialogue: We're picking up a distress call, Captain.

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: On speakers.

Speaker: com voice
Dialogue: This is the transport ship Lakul. We're caught in some kind of energy distortion. We can't break free... need immediate help... It' tearing us --

Speaker: science officer
Dialogue: The Lakul is one of two ships transporting El-Aurian refugees to Earth.

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: Can you locate them?

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: The ships are bearing at three one zero mark two one five. Distance: Three light years.

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: Signal the closest starship. We're in no condition to mount a rescue... We don't even have a full crew aboard.

Speaker: navigator
Dialogue: We're the only one in range, sir.

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: Well, then... I guess it's up to us.  Helm, lay in an intercept course and engage at maximum warp.

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: Is there something wrong with your chair, Captain?

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: We're within visual range of the energy distortion, Captain.

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: On screen.

Speaker: chekov
Dialogue: What the hell is that?

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: I've found the transport ships.

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: Their hulls are starting to buckle under the stress -- they won't survive much longer.

Speaker: navigator
Dialogue: We're encountering severe gravimetric distortions from the energy ribbon.

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: We'll have to keep our distance... we don't want to get pulled in too...

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Tractor beam...

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: We don't have a tractor beam.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: You left spacedock without a tractor beam?

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: It won't be installed until Tuesday.  Ensign Sulu... try generating a subspace field around the ships. That might break them free.

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: Aye, sir.

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: There's too much quantum interference, Captain.

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: What about... venting plasma from the warp nacelles? That might disrupt the ribbon's hold on the ships.

Speaker: navigator
Dialogue: Aye, sir.. releasing drive plasma...

Speaker: navigator
Dialogue: It's not having any effect, sir. I think --

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: Sir! The starboard vessel's hull is collapsing --

Speaker: chekov
Dialogue: How many people were aboard that ship?

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: Two hundred sixty-five.

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: The Lakul's hull integrity is down to twelve percent, sir.

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: Captain Kirk... I would appreciate any... suggestions you might have.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: First -- move us within transporter range and beam those people to the Enterprise.

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: What about the gravimetric distortions? They'll tear us apart...

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Risk is part of the game if you want to sit in that chair.

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: Helm, close to within transporter range.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: And second -- turn that damned thing off.

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: We're within range, sir.

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: Beam them directly to Sickbay.

Speaker: chekov
Dialogue: How big's your medical staff?

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: The medical staff... doesn't arrive until Tuesday.

Speaker: chekov
Dialogue: You and you. You've just become nurses. Let's go.

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: Main Engineering reports fluctuations in the warp plasma relays.

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: By-pass the relays and go to auxiliary systems.

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: Sir, I'm having trouble locking onto them. They appear to be... in some sort of... temporal flux.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Scotty?

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: What the hell...

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: Their life signs are... are phasing in and out of our space-time continuum.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Phasing? To where?

Speaker: navigator
Dialogue: Sir! Their hull's collapsing!

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: I got forty-seven of them...  ... out of one hundred fifty.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Report!

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: We're caught in a gravimetric field emanating from the trailing edge of the ribbon.

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: All engines, full reverse!

Speaker: survivors
Dialogue: The colors are touching me... I'm caught in the glass... Help me... I can see the seconds... Over here... etc

Speaker: chekov
Dialogue: It will be all right. We're going to take care of you.

Speaker: chekov
Dialogue: But it looks like they're all suffering from some kind of neural shock.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: Why...why?

Speaker: journalist
Dialogue: It's all right... you're safe... you're on the Enterprise.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: No... I have to go... I have to get back... You don't understand! Let me go!

Speaker: journalist
Dialogue: What was he talking about?

Speaker: chekov
Dialogue: Easy there...

Speaker: chekov
Dialogue: It's going to be okay. Here, just lie down.

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: Inertial dampers failing.

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: Engines not responding!

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: I didn't expect to die my first day on the job.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Scotty?

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: There's just no way to disrupt a gravimetric field of this magnitude!

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: Hull integrity failing.

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: But I do have a theory...

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: I thought you might.

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: An anti-matter discharge directly ahead... it might disrupt the field long enough for us to break away.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: A photon torpedo?

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: Aye.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Load torpedo bays, prepare to fire on my command.

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: Captain... we don't have any torpedoes.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Don't tell me... Tuesday.

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: Captain, it may be possible to simulate a torpedo blast using a resonance burst from the main deflector dish.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Where are the deflector relays?

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: Deck fifteen, section twenty-one alpha

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: I'll go. You have the Bridge.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: No... a Captain's place is on the Bridge of his ship.  I'll take care of it.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Keep her together until I get back.

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: I always do.

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: Forty-five seconds to structural collapse!

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: Bridge to Captain Kirk.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Kirk here.

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: Captain, I don't know how much longer I can hold her together!

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: That's it. Go!

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: Activate main deflector.

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: We're breaking free.

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: We're clear.

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: Damage report, Ensign.

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: We've also got a hull breach in the Engineering section. Emergency forcefields are in place and holding.

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: Where?

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: Sections twenty through twenty- eight on decks thirteen... fourteen...  ... and fifteen.

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: Captain Kirk, please respond.

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: Have Chekov meet me on deck fifteen.

Speaker: chekov
Dialogue: My God...  Was anyone in there?

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: Aye.

Speaker: demora
Dialogue: I've checked the entire ship and the surrounding space. there's no sign of him.

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: Just a quick... run around the block.

Speaker: chekov
Dialogue: I never thought it would end like this...

Speaker: scotty
Dialogue: All things must end, Mr. Chekov.

Speaker: harriman
Dialogue: Let's go home.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Bring out the prisoner!

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Mister Worf... I always knew this day would come. Are you prepared to face the charges?

Speaker: troi
Dialogue: Answer him!

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: I am prepared.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: "We, the officers and crew of the U.S.S. Enterprise, being of sound mind and judgment, hereby make the following charges against Lieutenant Worf: One. That he did knowingly and willfully perform above and beyond the call of duty on countless occasions. Two. That he has been a good and solid officer on this ship for one score less twelve years. And Three. Most seriously... that he has earned the respect and admiration of the entire crew."

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: There can be only one punishment for such crimes...  I hereby promote you to the rank of Lieutenant Commander, with all the rights and privileges thereto. And may God have mercy on your soul.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Congratulations, Commander.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Thank you, sir.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Extend the plank!!

Speaker: crewmembers
Dialogue: Into the sea with him... feed him to the sharks... walk the plank... etc.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Don't you think you're taking this a little too far, Number One?

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: When we went to ancient Rome for Deanna's promotion, we threw her to the lions, remember?

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: WAIT!!

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: I can't swim.

Speaker: la forge
Dialogue: The Holodeck safety program is engaged... The computer won't let you drown.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: But the sharks are quite convincing.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Doctor, I must confess I am uncertain as to why pushing someone into freezing, shark- infested water is amusing.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: It's all done in good fun, Data. Get in the spirit of things.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Ah.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: Data...Data -- !

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Data. that wasn't funny.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Well, now that we're all aboard...  Let's see what's out there.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Aye, aye, sir.  Take the wheel, Commander.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: All hands make sail! Raise up tacks and stand by the braces!

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Imagine what it was like, Will. No engines... no computers... just the wind, the sea and the stars to guide you.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Bad food, brutal discipline...  No women.

Speaker: com voice
Dialogue: Bridge to Captain Picard.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Picard here.

Speaker: com voice
Dialogue: There is a personal message for you from Earth.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: But the best thing about a life at sea was that they couldn't get to you.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Computer, arch.

Speaker: troi
Dialogue: Here. Take the wheel.

Speaker: troi
Dialogue: Captain, are you all right?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Yes. Fine. If you'll excuse me...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Computer, exit.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Set the royals and the studding sails, Mister Worf.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: The Royal... studs...?

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: You see the top yardarm, now look to the --

Speaker: com voice
Dialogue: Bridge to Commander Riker.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Riker here.

Speaker: com voice
Dialogue: We're picking up a distress call from the Amargosa observatory, sir. They say they're under attack.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Red Alert! All hands to Battle stations! Captain Picard to the Bridge.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: It looks like we're too late...

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: There are no other ships in the system.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Sensors show five life signs aboard the station, Captain.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: The station complement was nineteen.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Secure from Red Alert. Number One, begin an investigation. I'll be in my Ready Room.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Sir?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Make it so.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: These blast patterns are consistent with type-three disruptors.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Well, that narrows it to Klingon, Breen or Romulan.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: I'm picking up life signs... about twenty meters ahead.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: That rules out Klingons.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: They would not have left anyone alive.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: Over here.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Worf, you're with me. Paskall, you and Mendez search the upper deck.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Under here...

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: It's all right... do not struggle.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: I'm Commander William Riker of the Starship Enterprise.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: Soran... Doctor Tolian Soran...

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Who attacked you, Doctor?

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: I'm not sure... it happened so fast...

Speaker: security officer
Dialogue: Commander -- you'd better take a look at this.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Romulan.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Is she still angry?

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: No... but I'd stay out of Sickbay for a while if I were you. I still don't know why you dropped her in the water.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I was attempting to... get in the spirit of things. I thought it would be humorous.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Data... you're not thinking about using that thing are you?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: It has occurred to me on several occasions. But I believe this may be the appropriate time.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Wait a minute. I thought you've always been afraid it would overload your neural net.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: That is true. However, I believe my growth as an artificial life form has reached an impasse. For thirty-four years I have endeavored to become more "human" - to grow beyond my original programming. And yet I am still unable to grasp such a simple concept as humor.  This emotion chip is the only answer.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: All right...

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: But at the first sign of trouble, I'm going to deactivate it. agreed?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Agreed.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: We found two dead Romulans aboard the station. We're analyzing their equipment to see if we can determine what ship they came from.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: There's still no indication of why they attacked the station?

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: We think they were looking for something -- they practically tore the place apart.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Hmm...  Inform Starfleet Command. This could indicate a new Romulan threat in this sector.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: You want me to contact Starfleet?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Is there a problem?

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: No, sir.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Thank you, Number One.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: There is something else, Captain. One of the scientists. a Doctor Soran... has insisted on speaking with you.  I told him you were busy, sir, but he said it was absolutely imperative that he speak with you right away.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Understood. That will be all.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Sir... is there anything wrong?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: No. Thank you.

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: You two just volunteered to be my first victims.  This is a new concoction I picked up on Forcas Three. Trust me, you're going to love it.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Well...?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I believe the beverage has provoked an emotional response.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Really? What do you feel?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I am uncertain. I have had little experience with emotions... I am unable to articulate the sensation.

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: Emotions?

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: I'll explain later...

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: I don't think he likes it.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Yes. That is it. I hate it.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Data, I think the chip is working...

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Yes. I hate this! It is revolting!

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: Another round?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Please.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Doctor Soran...?

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: Yes, yes, Captain -- thank you for coming.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Nothing for me.  I understand there's something urgent you need to discuss with me.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: Yes. I need to return to the observatory immediately. I must continue a critical experiment I was running on the Amargosa star.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Doctor... we're still conducting an investigation into the attack. Once we've completed our work, we'll be happy to allow you and your fellow scientists back aboard the observatory. Until then --

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: The timing is very important on my experiment -- if it is not completed within the next twelve hours, years of research will be lost.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: We're doing the best we can. Now if you'll excuse me...

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: We leave so many things unfinished in our lives -- I'm sure you can understand.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I'll see what I can do...

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: One of the dead Romulans had a tricorder. We analyzed its sensor logs and found they were scanning for signature particles of a compound called trilithium.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Trilithium?

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: An experimental compound the Romulans have been working on. In theory, a trilithium-based explosive would be thousands of times more powerful than an anti-matter weapon. But they never found a way to stabilize it.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Why were they looking for it on a Federation observatory? It doesn't make any sense.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Have Geordi and Data go over with the next Away Team...  tell them to scan the observatory for trilithium.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Aye, sir.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: There's no sign of any trilithium in here.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I get it. I get it.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: You get what?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: When you said to Commander Riker...  "The clown can stay, but the Ferengi in the gorilla suit has to go."

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: During the Farpoint mission. We were on the Bridge and you told a joke. That was the punch line.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: The Farpoint mission? Data, that was seven years ago.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I know. I just got it.  It was very funny.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Wait a minute... there's a hidden doorway here. I can see the joint of the metal with my VISOR.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: There appears to be a dampening field in operation. I cannot scan beyond the bulkhead.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: I don't see a control panel...or an access port.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: It appears to be a magnetically sealed.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I believe I can reverse the polarity by attenuating my axial servo.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: "Open sesame."

Speaker: data
Dialogue: You could say I have a... magnetic personality.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: I'm still not picking up anything. Someone went to a lot of trouble to shield this room.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Data, take a look at this.  You ever seen a solar probe with this kind of configuration?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: No, Geordi. I have not. It is most unusual.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Just help me get this panel open.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Whoa. my VISOR'S picking up something in the theta band...it could be a trilithium signature.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Data, this isn't the time...

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I am sorry... but I cannot stop myself... I think something is wrong...

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Data!

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Data, are you all right?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I believe the emotional chip has overloaded my positronic relays.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: We better get you back to the Ship.  La Forge to Enterprise.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: Is there a problem, gentlemen?

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Oh... Doctor... yeah, as a matter of fact, there is. There's a damping field in here blocking our com signal.  Will you give me a hand?

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: I'd be happy to.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Please don't hurt me.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Tea. Earl Grey. Hot.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Come.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Counselor. What can I do for you?

Speaker: troi
Dialogue: Actually... I'm here to see if there's anything I can do for you.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Well... I appreciate your concern, but I'd rather not discuss it right now, thank you.

Speaker: troi
Dialogue: I'm afraid I can't just leave it at that. The commanding officer of this ship is clearly distraught about something. As ship's Counselor, it's my duty to --

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: As ship's counselor, it's your duty to know not only when you're needed... but also when you're not.

Speaker: troi
Dialogue: You can't fool an empath, Captain. I know exactly when I'm needed.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Well, with all due respect to your Betazoid senses, I prefer to be alone right now.

Speaker: troi
Dialogue: Very well. I suppose I could make out my weekly report to Starfleet Command without your input.  "Admiral Lusby... regarding the unusual behavior of Jean-Luc Picard: I find him increasingly Irritable... remote... and uncooperative. I recommend forced shore leave at a Starbase facility in order to --"

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: All right, all right. You've made your point.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: The message I received...  My brother... and his son -- my nephew -- burned to death in a fire.

Speaker: troi
Dialogue: Captain, I'm sorry.  I know there were a lot of unresolved conflicts between you and your brother.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: What I can't get out of my mind is the image of Rene -- my nephew. I just can't believe he's gone...

Speaker: troi
Dialogue: It's only natural to feel a heightened sense of tragedy when a child dies...  But it goes deeper than that, doesn't it? I can sense that Rene meant a great deal to you.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: In a way, he was as close as I ever came to having a child of my own.

Speaker: troi
Dialogue: Your family history is very important to you, isn't it?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Ever since I was a little boy, I remember hearing about the family line. The Picards that fought at Trafalgar... the Picard's that settled the first Martian colony. When my brother married and had a son...

Speaker: troi
Dialogue: ... You felt it was no longer your responsibility to carry on the family line.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: My brother had shouldered that burden... allowing me to pursue my own selfish needs...

Speaker: troi
Dialogue: There's nothing selfish about pursuing your own life... your own career.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: You know, Counselor... I'm not getting any younger. For some time now, I've been aware that there are fewer days ahead than there are behind...  But I always took comfort in the fact that when I was gone, my family would continue. But now...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I've had brushes with death... more than I care to contemplate. I always accepted it as a calculated risk that goes along with wearing this uniform.  But now... the idea of death has a terrible sense of finality to it.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I'm the last Picard.

Speaker: troi
Dialogue: Captain, perhaps we --

Speaker: riker's com voice
Dialogue: Red Alert! All hands to duty stations!

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Report.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: A quantum implosion has occurred within the Amargosa star. All nuclear fusion is breaking down.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: How is that possible?

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Sensor records show a solar probe was launched from the observatory a few moments ago.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: The star's going to collapse in a matter of minutes.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Sir, the implosion has produced a level twelve shock wave.

Speaker: troi
Dialogue: Level twelve? That'll destroy everything in this system.

Speaker: transporter com voice
Dialogue: Transporter room to Bridge. I can't locate Commander La Forge or Mister Data, sir.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Did they return to the ship?

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: No, sir. They are not aboard.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: How long until the shock wave hits the observatory?

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Four minutes, forty seconds.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Mister Worf.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: What the hell's he doing?

Speaker: picard's com voice
Dialogue: Enterprise to Commander Riker, you have two minutes left.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Soran, did you hear that? There's a level twelve shock wave coming. We've got to get out of here!

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: Sir. A Klingon Bird of Prey is decloaking off the port bow.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Data! See if you can get to Geordi!

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I... cannot, sir. I believe I Am... afraid.

Speaker: transporter com voice
Dialogue: Transporter room to Bridge. I have the Away Team aboard, sir.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Helm, warp one, engage.

Speaker: b'etor
Dialogue: Toh-pak-cha...

Speaker: lursa
Dialogue: HoS qorDu...

Speaker: b'etor
Dialogue: You've done it, Soran.

Speaker: b'etor
Dialogue: Wait!

Speaker: b'etor
Dialogue: I hope for your sake that you are initiating a mating ritual.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: You got careless. The Romulans came looking for their missing trilithium.

Speaker: b'etor
Dialogue: Impossible. We left no survivors on their outpost.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: They knew it was aboard the observatory. If the Enterprise hadn't intervened, they would have found it.

Speaker: lursa
Dialogue: But they didn't find it... and now we have a weapon of unlimited power.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: I have the weapon, Lursa. And if you ever want me to give it to you, I advise you to be a little more careful in the future.

Speaker: b'etor
Dialogue: Perhaps we are tired of waiting.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: Without my research... the trilithium is worthless... as are your plans to reconquer the Klingon Empire.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: Set course for the Veridian system. Maximum warp.

Speaker: klingon guard
Dialogue: What shall I do with this?

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: Bring him with me. I need some answers from Mr. La Forge.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: I have spoken to the Klingon High Council, sir. They identified the Bird of Prey as belonging to the Duras sisters.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Lursa and B'Etor...? This doesn't make any sense. A renowned stellar physicist somehow uses a trilithium probe to destroy a star, kidnaps Geordi... and escapes with a pair of Klingon renegades... Why? What the hell's going on?

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: How is he?

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: It looks like a power surge fused the emotional chip into his neural net.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Will that be a danger to him?

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: I don't think so. The chip still seems to be working. I'd feel better if I could take a closer look, but I can't remove it without completely dismantling his cerebral conduit.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Looks like you're stuck with emotions for a while. How do you feel?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I am quite... preoccupied with concern about Geordi.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: We all are, Data. But we're going to get him back.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I hope so, sir.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: Wil, I checked into Doctor Soran's background.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: He's an El-Aurian... over three hundred years old. He lost his entire family when the Borg destroyed his world. Soran escaped with a handful of other refugees aboard a ship called the Lakul. The ship was destroyed by some kind of energy ribbon, but Soran and forty-six others were rescued by the Enterprise-B.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: That was the mission where James Kirk was killed.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: I checked the passenger manifest of the Lakul... guess who else was on board?

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: Soran? That's a name I haven't heard in a long time.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Do you remember him?

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: Oh yes. I remember everyone who was on the Lakul... every face. even the ones who didn't make it...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Guinan. It's important that you tell me what you know. We think Soran's developed a weapon... a terrible weapon. It might give him enough power to --

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: Soran doesn't care about power or weapons. All he cares about is getting back to the Nexus.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: What's the "Nexus"?

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: It's a place I've tried very hard to forget...

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: That ribbon isn't just some random energy phenomenon traveling through space... it's a doorway. It leads to another place... the Nexus. It doesn't exist in our Universe... and it doesn't play by the same rules either.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: What happened to you?

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: I can't remember very much... what it looked like or how long I was there... but I do remember how it felt...

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: It was like being inside... joy. As if joy was a real thing that I could wrap around myself. I've never been so content...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: But then you were beamed away...

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: I was pulled away. I didn't want to leave; none of us did. I felt like I'd left a part of myself behind. All I could think about was getting back... I didn't care what I had to do.

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: It took a long time, but eventually I learned to live with it. And I began to realize that my experience in the Nexus had changed me...  I knew things about people... about events...about time...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Your "sixth sense"... I've always wondered where it came from...  And what about Soran?

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: Soran may still be obsessed with getting back. And if he is, he'll do anything to find that doorway again.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: But why destroy a star...?  Thank you, Guinan.

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: Let someone else do it, Jean-Luc.

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: Let them send another starship. Don't get near the ribbon. If you go into that Nexus, you're not going to care about Soran or the Enterprise or me. All you're going to care about is how it feels to be there.  And you're never going to come back.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: Have you ever considered a prosthesis that would make you look a little more... normal?

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: What's normal?

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: Normal is what everyone else is... and what you are not.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: As you may or may not be aware, I am an El-Aurian. Some people call us a race of "listeners". We listen.  Right now, Mr. La Forge, you have my undivided attention. I want to listen to everything you know about trilithium. and me.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Trilithium is an experimental compound developed by the Romulans. I think it's a derivative of --

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: I don't want a science lecture. You were on that observatory looking for trilithium... why?

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: I was ordered to by the Captain.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: Let's try to move beyond the usual prisoner-interrogator banter, shall we? You have information, and I need it.  Did the Captain explain his orders to you? Did he say why you were searching for trilithium?

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: What about... Guinan? What has she told you about me?

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Guinan? I don't know what you're talking about...

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: My instincts tell me you're lying. And I know that can't be easy for you...  I can see you have a good heart.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: Oh... I forgot to tell you. While you were unconscious, I injected a nano-probe into your bloodstream. It's been navigating your cardiovascular system... and right now I've attached it to your left ventricle.  A little trick I picked up from the Borg.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Yeah... they're full of great ideas.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: I just stopped your heart for five seconds. It felt like an eternity, didn't it? Did you know that you can stop the human heart for up to ten minutes before the onset of brain damage?

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: No... I didn't know that...

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: We learn something new about ourselves every day.  Now. Maybe I didn't make myself clear. It is very important that you tell me exactly what Captain Picard knows.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: I told you everything... you might as well just kill me right now...

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: I'm not a killer, Mr. La Forge.  Let's try thirty seconds.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: According to our information, the ribbon is a conflux of temporal energy which travels through our galaxy every thirty-nine point one years

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: When is it expected back?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Data?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Sorry, Captain. The Ribbon has already entered the galaxy. It will pass through this sector in approximately thirty-one hours.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Guinan said Soran was trying to get back to the ribbon... if that's true, then there must be some connection with the Amargosa star.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: The star's destruction has had numerous astro-physical effects within this sector. However, none of them appear to have a connection to the energy ribbon.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Give me a list of those effects. I want to know every single thing which has been altered or changed... no matter how insignificant...

Speaker: data
Dialogue: It will take a few moments for the computer to compile the information.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Data, are you all right?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: No, sir. I am finding it difficult to concentrate... I believe I am overwhelmed with feelings of... remorse and regret concerning my actions on the observatory.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I wanted to save Geordi... I tried. but I experienced something I did not expect.  I believe it was fear.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Fear is a very difficult emotion to overcome. It's something we all have to learn to deal with.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: But I did not deal with it, sir. I let it prevent me from helping my friend.  Does that make me a coward?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: No. And what you must try to avoid is becoming consumed by another emotion which I believe you're beginning to experience... guilt.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Guilt. It is a most unpleasant feeling.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: According to our current information, the destruction of the Amargosa star has had the following effects in this sector: gamma emissions have increased by five percent... the starship Bozeman was forced to make a course correction... a research project on Gorik Four was halted due to increased neutrino particles... ambient magnetic fields have decreased by --

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Wait. The Bozeman... why did it change course?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: The destruction of the Amargosa star has altered the gravitational forces throughout the sector. Any ship passing through this region will have to make a minor course correction.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Where is the ribbon now?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: This is its current position.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Can you project its course?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Data. I have nothing but sympathy for what you're going through. But right now, I need your full attention on the task at hand. If you can't provide it... then I'll have to relieve you of duty until Doctor Crusher can remove this. emotion chip of yours. I'm sorry, but you leave me no other choice.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I do not wish to remove the chip, sir. Although these emotions are proving difficult to deal with... I cannot imagine going back to a life without them. I have taken an important step toward becoming truly human. If I were to turn back now...  I would like to continue in my duties, sir.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Courage is an emotion too, Data.  Now... can you project the course of the ribbon?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I believe so.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Enhance grid A-nine.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Where was the Amargosa star?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Now... you said the gravitational forces in this sector have been altered... could that also affect the course of the ribbon?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I believe so.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: That's what Soran's doing... he's changing its course.  But why? Why try to alter its path... why not simply fly into it with a ship?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Our records show that every ship which has approached the ribbon has either been destroyed or severely damaged.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: He can't go to the ribbon... so he's trying to make the ribbon come to him.  Data, is it going to pass near any M-Class planets?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Yes, sir. There are two in the Veridian system.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: It's very close to Veridian Three... but not close enough...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Data, what would happen to the ribbon's path if he destroyed the Veridian star itself?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: That's where he's going.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: It should be noted, sir, that the collapse of the Veridian star would produce a shock wave similar to the one we observed at Amargosa.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: And destroy every planet in the system.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Are any of them inhabited?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Veridian Three is uninhabited. but Veridian Four supports a pre- industrial humanoid society.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Population?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Approximately two hundred thirty million.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Picard to Bridge.

Speaker: worf's com voice
Dialogue: Worf here, sir.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Red Alert, Mister Worf. Set a course for the Veridian system, maximum warp.

Speaker: lursa
Dialogue: Did you get anything from the human?

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: No. His heart just isn't in it.

Speaker: klingon helm
Dialogue: We have entered orbit of Veridian Three.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: Prepare to transport me to the surface.

Speaker: b'etor
Dialogue: Wait. When do we get our payment?

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: This contains all the information you'll need to build a trilithium weapon. It's been coded. Once I'm safely to the surface, I'll transmit the decryption sequence to you... not before.

Speaker: klingon helm
Dialogue: Mistress! -- a Federation starship is entering the system!

Speaker: lursa
Dialogue: What? On viewer.

Speaker: klingon helm
Dialogue: They are hailing us.

Speaker: b'etor
Dialogue: Du'cha

Speaker: picard's com voice
Dialogue: Klingon vessel. We know what you're doing, and we will destroy any probe launched toward the Veridian star.

Speaker: b'etor
Dialogue: What do we do?

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: There's no time for this. Eliminate them.

Speaker: b'etor
Dialogue: That is a Galaxy class Starship. We are no match for them.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: I think it's time we gave Mister La Forge his sight back.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Maybe they're not out there.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: They're just trying to decide whether a twenty year-old Klingon Bird of Prey is any match for the Federation flagship.

Speaker: troi
Dialogue: Or perhaps they're on the surface...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Mister Data, scan the planet for life forms.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I was hoping you would ask me to do that, Captain. I just love to scan for life forms.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: "Life forms... tiny little life forms... where are the life forms --"

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Commander.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Sorry, sir.  There is too much interference in the planet's ionosphere for an accurate reading.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Sir, according to my calculations, a solar probe launched from either the Klingon ship or the planet's surface will take eleven seconds to reach the star.  However, since we do not know the exact point of origin, it will take us between eight and fifteen seconds to lock our weapons onto it.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: That's a pretty big margin of error.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Too big. How long until the ribbon arrives?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Approximately forty-seven minutes, sir.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I have to find a way to get to Soran...

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Captain, Klingon vessel decloaking directly ahead.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: They are hailing.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: On screen.

Speaker: lursa
Dialogue: Captain. What an unexpected pleasure.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Lursa, I want to talk to Soran.

Speaker: lursa
Dialogue: I'm afraid the Doctor is no longer aboard our ship.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Then I'll beam down to his location. Just give us his coordinates.

Speaker: b'etor
Dialogue: The Doctor values his privacy. He would be quite... upset if an Away Team interrupted him.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Very well... I'll beam to your ship and you can transport me to Soran...

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Sir, you can't trust them. They'll kill you just like they Killed Geordi.

Speaker: lursa
Dialogue: We did not kill your Engineer. He's been... our guest.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Then return him.

Speaker: b'etor
Dialogue: In exchange for what?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Me... If you let me speak to Soran.

Speaker: b'etor
Dialogue: The Captain would make a much more valuable hostage.

Speaker: lursa
Dialogue: We'll consider it a prisoner exchange.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Agreed.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Number One, you have the Bridge. Have Doctor Crusher meet me in Transporter Room Three.

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: Receiving the coordinates, Captain.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Energize.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: You must think I'm quite the madman.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: The thought had crossed my mind...

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: The only possible reason you're here is because you're not entirely confident you can shoot down my probe after all. So you've come to dissuade me from my horrific plan.  Good luck.

Speaker: klingon helm
Dialogue: I have established the link.

Speaker: lursa
Dialogue: Put it through over here.

Speaker: lursa
Dialogue: It's working...

Speaker: b'etor
Dialogue: Where is he?

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: Don't worry, there's been no permanent damage. Your heart is perfectly fine. There's been a little arterial damage...

Speaker: b'etor
Dialogue: Human females are so repulsive.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: ... and some myocardial degeneration. I'm going to give you some hematozine, and I want to run more tests... but I think you're going to be fine.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Thanks, Doc.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: You don't need to do this, Soran... I'm sure we could find another way to get you into this Nexus.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: Of course, you could always come with me. You fancy yourself an explorer. Here's a chance to explore something no human has ever experienced.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Not if it means killing over two hundred million people.  I wonder... did your wife Leandra know that she married a man who was capable of mass murder?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: When you tucked your children into bed... do you suppose they ever suspected that their father would one day kill millions as casually as he kissed them goodnight?

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: Nice try.

Speaker: b'etor
Dialogue: I thought he was the Chief Engineer.

Speaker: lursa
Dialogue: He is.

Speaker: b'etor
Dialogue: Then when is he going to Engineering?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: What you're about to do is no different from when the Borg destroyed your world.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: You're right. And there was a time when I wouldn't have hurt anyone. Then the Borg came... and they showed me that if there is one constant in this universe, it's death.  Afterwards, I began to realize that none of it mattered. We're all going to die anyway. It's only a question of how and when. You will too, Captain. You might contract a fatal disease... you might die in battle...

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: ... or burn to death in a fire.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: You looked surprised. But you shouldn't be. I've been to the Nexus, Captain. I know things about people.  Aren't you beginning to feel time gaining on you? It's like a predator. It's stalking you. You can try to outrun it with doctors... medicines.new technologies... but in the end, time is going to hunt you down... and make the kill.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: We're all. mortal, Soran. It's one of the truths of our existence.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: What if I told you I found a new truth...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: The Nexus.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: Time has no meaning there. The predator has no teeth.

Speaker: lursa
Dialogue: Where is he now?

Speaker: b'etor
Dialogue: I don't know... he bathed... now he is roaming the ship. He must be the only Engineer in Starfleet who does not go to Engineering!

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: Careful, Captain. That's a fifty gigawatt forcefield. I wouldn't want to see you get hurt.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: b'etor
Dialogue: Finally!

Speaker: farrell
Dialogue: I'd like to run a Level Three diagnostic on the port plasma relays. I think one of the generators is fluctuating.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Okay, let's do it.

Speaker: lursa
Dialogue: That's it!  Replay from time index four-two- nine.

Speaker: lursa
Dialogue: Magnify this section and enhance.

Speaker: lursa
Dialogue: Their shields are operating on a modulation of two-five-seven point four...

Speaker: b'etor
Dialogue: Adjust our torpedo frequency to match - two-five-seven point four!

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Sir, I am detecting an anomalous subspace reading in Main Engineering. It may be --

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: They have found a way to penetrate our shields.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Lock phasers and return fire!

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Deanna, take the helm. Get us out of orbit.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Hull breach on decks thirty-one Through thirty-five.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Worf, that's an old Klingon ship. What do we know about it? Are there any weaknesses?

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: It is a Class D-twelve Bird of Prey. They were retired from service because of defective plasma coils.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Plasma coils... is there any way we can use that to our advantage?

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: I do not see how. The plasma coil is part of their cloaking device...

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Get a stabilizer on that conduit.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Could we access the defective coil and trigger their cloak?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Yes! If we sent a low-level ionic pulse, it might reset the coil and engage the cloaking systems.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: As their cloak begins to engage, their shields will drop.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Right. And they'll be vulnerable for at least two seconds.  Data, lock onto that plasma coil.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: No problem.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Worf, prepare a spread of photon torpedoes. We'll have to hit them the instant they begin to cloak.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Aye, sir.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: We're only going to get one shot at this. Target their primary reactor. With any luck, their warp core should implode.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I have accessed their coil frequency... initiating ionic pulse...

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Make it quick!

Speaker: lursa
Dialogue: Target their Bridge.

Speaker: b'etor
Dialogue: Full disruptors.

Speaker: klingon helm
Dialogue: We are cloaking!

Speaker: b'etor
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: klingon helm
Dialogue: Mistress -- our shields are down!

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Fire!

Speaker: data
Dialogue: YES!!

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: Don't you have anything better to do?

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: La Forge to Bridge. I've got a problem down here. The magnetic interlocks have been ruptured. I need to get the --

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Coolant leak! Everybody out.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Bridge, we've got a new problem. We're about five minutes from a Warp core breach. There's nothing I can do.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Mister Data, prepare to separate the ship.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: Now, if you'll excuse me, Captain, I have an appointment with eternity and I don't want to be late.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: That's it, Bridge -- we're all out!

Speaker: data
Dialogue: One minute to warp core breach.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Full impulse power once we're clear.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Separation complete. Ten seconds to warp core breach.

Speaker: troi
Dialogue: Engaging impulse engines.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Report.

Speaker: troi
Dialogue: Helm controls are off-line!

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Oh, shit.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I have rerouted auxiliary power to the lateral thrusters. I'm attempting to level our descent...

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: All hands, brace for impact!

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: What's going on? Where am I?

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Go on... say something. They're waiting.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I... don't know what to say...

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Say Merry Christmas, Papa!

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Merry... Christmas...

Speaker: children
Dialogue: This one's for you... where's mine?... I hope this is the book I asked for... take this one to Papa...

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Isn't the tree beautiful, Papa?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Oh yes... yes, it's astonishingly beautiful. All of it.

Speaker: young boy
Dialogue: This is from all of us.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Thank you... I can't imagine what it is.

Speaker: young boy
Dialogue: It's a sack-tent!

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: You mean a sextant. And it's a handsome one at that... from about eighteen twenty, I'd say. Wherever did you find it?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: It's a secret.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Oh, a secret... well, that makes it a doubly special gift. Thank you... thank you all...

Speaker: children
Dialogue: Merry Christmas, Papa... I love You, Father... etc.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: I'll go get dinner ready. they'll be starving in a minute.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: No... this isn't right... this can't be real...

Speaker: guinan's voice
Dialogue: It's as real as you want it to be.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Guinan... what's going on? Where am I?

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: You're in the Nexus.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: This... is the Nexus?

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: For you. This is where you wanted to be...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: But I never had a wife, children, a home like this...

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: Enjoy them, Jean-Luc...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Guinan, what are you doing here? I thought you were on the Enterprise.

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: I am on the Enterprise...I am also here.  Think of me as... an "echo" of the person you know... a part of her she left behind...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Left behind...?

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: When the Enterprise-B beamed us off the Lakul, we were partially in the Nexus. The transporters locked on to us... but somehow everyone left a part of themselves behind.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Soran...?

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: All of us.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Where is he now?

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: Wherever he wanted to be...

Speaker: boy's voice
Dialogue: Papa, help me build my castle!

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: In a few minutes...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: These are my children... my children...

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: Yeah. They're great, aren't they? You can go back and see them born... go forward and see your grandchildren... time has no meaning here.

Speaker: woman's voice
Dialogue: Dinner's ready! Let's go!

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: Papa... are you coming?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Go on... go on without me...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Guinan... can I leave the Nexus?

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: Why would you want to leave?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Can I?

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: Yes... where would you go?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I don't understand.

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: I told you, time has no meaning here. If you leave, you can go anywhere... any time.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I know exactly where I want to go... and when. Back to that mountaintop on Veridian Three... before Soran put out the star. I have to stop him.

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: What makes you think things will be any different this time?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: You're right. I'll need help.  Guinan, will you come back with me? Together, we could --

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: I can't leave. I'm already there, remember?

Speaker: guinan
Dialogue: I know just the guy.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: James Kirk.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Beautiful day, isn't it?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Yes... yes, it is.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Do you mind?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Captain, do you realize what --

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Wait a second. I think something's burning.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Looks like someone was cooking eggs...  Come on in, it's all right. This is my house -- or at least it used to be, I sold it years ago.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I'm Captain Jean-Luc Picard of the starship Enterprise.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: This clock... I gave this clock to Bones...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I'm from what you would consider the future... the twenty-fourth century.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: He's been dead seven years.

Speaker: antonia's voice
Dialogue: Come on, Jim, I'm starving. How long are you going to be rattling around that kitchen?

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: That's Antonia...

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Wait a minute...

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: The future... what are you talking about? This is the past...

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: This is nine years ago... the day I told her I was going back to Starfleet...

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: These were Ktarian eggs -- her favorite.I was cooking them to soften the blow...  And I gave her this.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I know how real this must seem to you, but it's not. This isn't Really your house. We've both been caught up in some sort of temporal nexus.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Dill weed.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: There's a bottle of dill weed on the second shelf to the left, right behind the nutmeg.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: How long have you been here?

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: I don't know. I was on the Enterprise-B... in the deflector control room... keep stirring these, will you?

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: History records that you died saving the Enterprise-B from an energy ribbon eighty years ago...

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: So you're telling me this is the twenty-fourth century... and I'm dead?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Not exactly. As I said, this is some kind of...

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Temporal nexus... yeah, I heard you.  Something's missing...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Captain, I need your help. I want you to leave the Nexus with me.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: We have to go back to a planet called Veridian III and stop a man from destroying a star. There are millions of lives at stake.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: You said history considers me dead. Who am I to argue with history?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: You're a Starfleet Officer and you have a duty to --

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: I was like you once... so worried about duty and obligations that I couldn't see anything past this uniform. And in the end, what did it get me? Nothing. Not this time.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: I'm going to walk up these stairs, march into that bedroom and tell Antonia that I want to marry her.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: This time things are going to be different.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: This doesn't look like your bedroom.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: No... no, it's not. It's better.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Better?

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: This is my uncle's barn in Iowa...

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: I took that horse out for a ride seven years ago... on a spring day.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Just like this. If I'm right, this is the day I met Antonia.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: This Nexus of yours is very clever. I can start all over again -- do things right from day one.

Speaker: cut to:
Dialogue: 166   EXT. COUNTRYSIDE - DAY                              166  Kirk is riding his horse hard over the countryside -- and across a stream... through a thicket of trees... and finally out onto a rolling plain. There is a large RAVINE up ahead. Kirk sees it and smiles tightly. He spurs his horse faster toward the ravine... The horse is tearing along... comes up to the edge of the precipice, and makes a daring leap to the other side.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Because... it's not real.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Antonia?

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: She's not real either, is she? Nothing here is... nothing here matters...

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: It's kinda like... orbital skydiving. Exciting for a few minutes... but in the end, you haven't really done anything... you haven't made a difference...

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Captain of the Enterprise, huh?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Close to retirement?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I hadn't planned on it.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Well, let me tell you something - don't. Don't let them promote you... don't let them transfer you... don't let anything take you off the Bridge of that ship...  Because while you're there, you can make a difference.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: You don't need to be on the Bridge of a starship. Come with me. Help me stop Soran.  Make a difference again.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: How can I argue with the Captain of the Enterprise?  What was the name of that Planet... Veridian III?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: I take it the odds are against us, and the situation is grim?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: You could say that.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Of course, if Spock were here, he'd say I was being an irrational, illogical human for wanting to go on a mission like that...

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Sounds like fun.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: Now, if you'll excuse me, Captain, I have an appointment with Eternity and I don't want to be late.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Kirk -- there's a control PADD in his right pocket!

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: The twenty-fourth century isn't so tough.

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: No...

Speaker: soran
Dialogue: YOU!!

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Nice shot.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I'll find a way to contact the Enterprise. You're going to be all right.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Did we do it? Did we make a Difference...?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Yes.  Thank you.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: Least I could do...for a Captain of the Enterprise.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Try to hang on.

Speaker: kirk
Dialogue: It was fun.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Captain, are you all right?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: la forge
Dialogue: What about Doctor Soran?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: You needn't worry about the Doctor anymore.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Was there a problem with the Klingons?

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: You could say that...

Speaker: ogawa
Dialogue: That should be the last of the wounded, Doctor.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: Two hundred thirty-two patients in under two days.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: Save that stretcher...

Speaker: ogawa
Dialogue: Is there another patient?

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: No -- that one's for me.

Speaker: troi
Dialogue: Over here, Data! I think I've found something.

Speaker: troi
Dialogue: One life sign, very faint.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Spot.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I am very happy to find you, Spot.

Speaker: troi
Dialogue: Another family reunited.

Speaker: troi
Dialogue: Data... are you all right?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I am not sure, Counselor. I am happy to see Spot... and yet I am crying. My emotional program must be malfunctioning again.

Speaker: troi
Dialogue: No, Data... I think it's working perfectly.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Is this it?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Yes, Number One. Thank you.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: I'm going to miss this ship. She went before her time.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: It's not how many years you've lived, Wil... but how you've lived them.  We are after all. only mortal.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Speak for yourself, sir. I kinda planned on living forever.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: I always thought I'd have a crack at this chair one day.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: You may still... somehow I doubt this will be the last ship to carry the name Enterprise.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Picard to Farragut. Two to beam up.
